Intermediate Vocabulary - Page 4

Intermediate

Intermediate Vocabulary - Page 4

Enhance your vocabulary with these important intermediate words commonly used in academic and professional contexts.

Navigation

This is page 4 of 15. Use the navigation below to explore all vocabulary pages.

Word List

Particular

/pərˈtɪkjələr/

adjective

Used to emphasize that something refers to one specific thing or person.

"I'm looking for a particular book about history."

Synonyms: specific, certain, special

Category: Specification

Perspective

/pərˈspektɪv/

noun

A particular attitude toward or way of regarding something; a point of view.

"From my perspective, the project was a success."

Synonyms: viewpoint, outlook, angle

Category: Opinion

Phenomenon

/fəˈnɑːmənən/

noun

A fact or situation that is observed to exist or happen.

"The northern lights are a fascinating natural phenomenon."

Synonyms: occurrence, event, manifestation

Category: Science

Potential

/pəˈtenʃəl/

adjective, noun

Having or showing the capacity to become or develop into something.

"She has great potential as a musician."

Synonyms: possible, capability, promise

Category: Ability

Preliminary

/prɪˈlɪməˌneri/

adjective

Denoting an action or event preceding or done in preparation for something.

"The preliminary results look promising."

Synonyms: initial, preparatory, introductory

Category: Preparation

Primarily

/ˈpraɪˌmerəli/

adverb

For the most part; mainly.

"The company is primarily focused on software development."

Synonyms: mainly, chiefly, mostly

Category: Emphasis

Procedure

/prəˈsiːdʒər/

noun

An established or official way of doing something.

"Please follow the safety procedure during the experiment."

Synonyms: process, method, protocol

Category: Method

Proportion

/prəˈpɔːrʃən/

noun

A part, share, or number considered in comparative relation to a whole.

"A large proportion of students passed the exam."

Synonyms: ratio, percentage, fraction

Category: Mathematics

Pursue

/pərˈsuː/

verb

To follow or chase someone or something; to continue or proceed along a path.

"She decided to pursue a career in medicine."

Synonyms: follow, chase, seek

Category: Action

Remarkable

/rɪˈmɑːrkəbəl/

adjective

Worthy of attention; striking or extraordinary.

"The artist showed remarkable talent at a young age."

Synonyms: extraordinary, outstanding, impressive

Category: Quality

Reluctant

/rɪˈlʌktənt/

adjective

Unwilling and hesitant; disinclined.

"He was reluctant to share his personal experiences."

Synonyms: unwilling, hesitant, disinclined

Category: Attitude

Significant

/sɪɡˈnɪfɪkənt/

adjective

Sufficiently great or important to be worthy of attention; noteworthy.

"There was a significant improvement in test scores."

Synonyms: important, notable, considerable

Category: Importance
